intro: Zappania arabica, commonly known as the Arabian coffee plant, is a species native to the highlands of Ethiopia and Yemen. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 meters, with dark green, leathery leaves. The plant produces small, white flowers that give way to red, fleshy berries containing the seeds used for coffee. Its botanical characteristics include a woody stem, opposite leaf arrangement, and a unique fruit structure. Zappania arabica is notable for its role in the production of Arabica coffee, one of the most widely consumed coffee varieties worldwide.
